isis.stitle: GENERAL INSTRUMENT ELECTRONIC PROGRAMMABLE SPEEDOMETER/TACHOMETER - OPERATION

svcsubsecinfo.para: The speedometer/tachometer unit consists of four serviceable components: the unit housing which includes the printed circuit board that drives all of the meters, the speedometer and tachometer which are air core gauges, and the odometer.

The speedometer/tachometer unit receives B+ voltage whenever the key switch is in the ON position (with Cat 3406B with PEEC and Kysor shutdown the engine must be started). The unit has a single power source and a single ground. The speedometer/tachometer unit wiring connections are shown in Figure 2. Also refer to circuit diagrams in this section.

The speedometer/tachometer unit data link connector is not currently used in the vehicle operating system, but the assembly plants do use it to program the speedometer/tachometer unit dip switches electronically.

The two-speed connector is present in all speedometer/tachometer units as it is used with a test harness (that is discussed later) to diagnose the speedometer/tachometer unit even if the vehicle does not have a two-speed axle.

The speedometer/tachometer dash unit receives alternating current (AC) signals from the speedometer sensor located in the transmission, and the engine speed sensor located in the engine flywheel housing.

The sensors contain a permanent magnet ( Figure 3) that creates a magnetic field that when broken by a rotating gear, generates an A.C. voltage that is transmitted to the speedometer/tachometer unit. A computer module in the housing (printed circuit board) counts the impulses and computes the vehicle speed in miles-per-hour (or kilometers-per-hour) and the engine speed in revolutions-per-minute (RPM). This information is used to drive the air core speedometer and tachometer and the odometer.

The low range of the speedometer/tachometer unit for two-speed axle applications is activated by the application of 12 volts (B+ voltage) on the single black lead of the speedometer/tachometer unit. The voltage source is a pressure switch located in the axle shift air line. When the voltage is delivered to the speedometer/tachometer unit, the computer divides the speedometer sensor input by 1.36 and the reading of the speedometer and odometer changes accordingly.
